phrases.content: Build an indoor fort. Challenge your kids to get creative using sheets, blankets, boxes, rope, duct tape, and newspaper.  Wrapping paper and holiday lights make for great decorations!
Do science experiments. Science Fun for Everyone has great ideas for easy and safe experiments that you can do at home with kids of all ages.
Hide a prize and leave clues to find it. Treasure hunts can be easy to create by searching online for kid-friendly riddles and clues!
Bake cookies. Check out the BBC’s Goodfood website for recipe ideas for kids.
Set up a painting and craft station. Parents magazine has easy and inexpensive craft ideas for kids of all ages.
Make paper airplanes. Origami Way has easy to follow instructions for folding paper airplanes and spacecrafts!
Have a dance party. Take turns playing your favorite songs or encourage your kids to record their own music video.
Play dress up. Choose your favorite characters from books, movies, and TV, and hunt for clothing items to dress up and act like them.
Read a story.
Make up your own story together.
Put your favorite activity ideas in a hat to randomly choose from.
Play a board game.
Invent a board game.
Hold an American Idol competition and sing or lip synch your favorite songs.
Create a scavenger hunt. Good Housekeeping has creative tips for scavenger hunt themes!
Do a puzzle together.
Plant an indoor herb garden together.
Create an obstacle course and compete to see who is the fastest. It is easy to search online for safe activities to include for kids of all ages.
Make cards or write letters to send to loved ones.
Virtually visit the Monterey Bay Aquarium! Check out the world-famous otters and more, all set to calming background music (available 7 am - 6 pm PST).
Try a virtual movie night with friends or family! Download the Google Chrome extension and you can stream the same show at the same time.
Bake something. The Food Network has a wide variety of recipe ideas that won’t add to your stress.
Cook a meal for yourself. Pure Wow can help you brainstorm some simple dishes.
Dance. Dance magazine has a list of online dance classes you can take and free tutorials you can watch.
Do a crossword or Sudoku puzzle.
Do a jigsaw puzzle.
Do arts and crafts. Joann’s has all kinds of ideas!
Eat something delicious.
Have coffee or tea.
Knit or do needlepoint. The NY Times posted a helpful online article with tips for how to start knitting.
Light some candles.
List 5 things you like about yourself.
Listen to the radio.
Paint or draw.
Plan a trip for the future. Fodor’s Travel website has fun ideas for every kind of getaway,  including budget friendly ideas.
Play cards. Bicycle shares some great solo card games!
Play with animals
Practice a martial art.
Pray, meditate, or practice yoga.
Put on an outfit that makes you feel good.
Read a relaxing magazine or book.
Remember a fun vacation.
Remember someone being kind to you.
Sew, knit or crochet.
Sing around the house.
Take a warm bath.
Take photographs. It is easy to search online for  creative photo projects you can work on from home.
Think about someone you love.
Watch a movie or TV show.
Watch funny videos.
Watch past sports highlights on TV or online.
Write a poem or story. Oprah.com’s tips can help you get started!
Put on your favorite shirt to “feel good”.
Take a relaxing shower.
Build something with your hands. Popular Mechanics has plenty of ideas for hands on projects you can do at home.
Have a virtual museum day. Take advantage of twelve renowned museums that offer a virtual tour, including New York's Guggenheim, Musée d'Orsay in Paris, and Uffizi Gallery in Florence, Italy.
Listen to music. KCRW curates a unique mix of music around news and cultural exploration. You can check out their content through their app or online.
Make ice cream sundaes or create your own chocolate tasting where you sample and compare what you are tasting.
Make dinner. BBC’s Goodfood website offers a variety of free recipes online that cater to healthy eating, families, and foodies alike.
Make a sightseeing list. Share your bucket list of places you want to travel to or visit in your city. Search online for fun itineraries or activities you’ve never tried.
Read aloud to each other.
Read and have coffee or tea.
Watch a performance of theater play online. Filmed On Stage has a library of free productions you can watch from home.
Visit a museum online.
Visit an online church/temple/mosque.
Watch a movie. Rotten Tomatoes has a list of 200 essential movies to watch from the 1920s to today!
Take an online class in a craft, a language, or a dance. Open Culture will direct you to free resources for learning a new language!
Volunteer at an online school. Upchieve supports low-income high schoolers with free volunteer tutors. Anyone can become a volunteer!
Play each other your favorite songs.
Create a music playlist for the morning, evening, and night.
Take an online yoga class.
Teach each other a skill the other person doesn’t know
Play cards. Bicycle has card game recommendations for classic card games.
Rearrange your living space.
Clean. Country Living has some great cleaning tips.
Play a board game.
Set up an online party.
Write a song. BBC’s Bitesize has a great step by step process for beginners!
Create a donation box and add to it.
Plan the week’s meals.
Work out.  Good Housekeeping has a great list of ways you can keep fit at home!
Make a list of your favorite movies. Share them with one another.
Bake. The Food Network offers a list of baking recipes that won’t add to your stress.
